Chapter 3 Plotting data with ggplot In the literature, the most common way to visualize \(\epsilon\)205Tl is plotted against 1/Tl concentration (ppm), so this is why I made the merged sheet during my last stage of cleaning. Thanks to recent practice from class assignments, plotting the data to share with my collaborators was the easieast part. # load packages library(tidyverse) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(knitr) # remind RMarkdown that iso_el = merged_data.csv (had some trouble with this) iso_el <- read.csv("merged_data.csv") # Tl isotope and 1/Tl plot (note to self: low Tl conc outlier cropped out in this version) tl_plot <- iso_el %>% ggplot(aes(x = Tl_inv, y = mean, col = combined_names)) + geom_point(aes(shape = month)) + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = mean - sd2, ymax = mean + sd2), width = .2)+ theme_light() + labs(x = "1/Tl (ppm)", y = "expression(epsilon)", col = "Site", shape = "Month") + theme(legend.position = c(0.85,0.3)) + xlim(0, 20) + ggsave(filename = "tl_plot.tiff", device = "tiff", width = 8, height = 8, units = "in", dpi = 400) tl_plot # hopefully insert the plot... it's taking forever to load! knitr::include_graphics("tl_plot.tiff") Figure 3.1: The plot.
